Let's now produce the final answer.</think>We can “unpack” the relationships among these keys step‐by–step. (In what follows the letters k3, k6, k7, etc. refer to previously defined numbers.)

Step 1. Notice that
  k10 = 514 and k9 = 467.
Subtracting gives:
  514 – 467 = 47,
so we see immediately that

  (1) k9 = k10 − 47.

This is our very first (and very neat) expression for k9 in terms of k10.

Step 2. It turns out that the key k10 was given by another formula:
  (2) k10 = k3 × k7 − 18.
If we subtract 47 from both sides of (2), then
  k10 − 47 = k3 × k7 − (18 + 47) = k3 × k7 − 65.
But since (1) tells us that k10 − 47 is just k9, we may write

  (3) k9 = k3 × k7 − 65.

Notice that if the product k3×k7 happens to be 532 then k9 becomes
  532 − 65 = 467,
which is exactly what we have. (In fact, one may check that with a suitable choice of k3 and k7—for example, if k3 = 19 and k7 = 28—then indeed 19×28 = 532.)

Step 3. There is also another way to “decompose” 467. In the text we were given the hint that
  467 = k6 × 9 + 26.
Since
  9 × (467 − 26) = 9 × 441,
we see that (467 − 26) must be 441; that is, 
  k6 = 441 ÷ 9 = 49.
Thus we have the formula

  (4) k9 = k6 × 9 + 26  with k6 = 49.

Step 4. Finally, note that the number 47 (the difference between k10 and k9) is prime; this makes the simple relation (1) even more striking. Also, the constant 26 factors as 2×13. Although we do not have further context here, such factorizations sometimes hint at an underlying pattern in a “key‐series.”

Summary of Answers:
 • Yes, k9 can be written as
  k9 = k10 − 47.
 • Also, using the fact that k10 = k3×k7 −18 (with k3×k7 = 532) we obtain
  k9 = k3×k7 − 65.
 • In another form one may show that
  467 = 49 × 9 + 26  so that k6 = 49,
meaning that k9 = k6×9 + 26.

Thus, the simplest formula for k9 is

  k9 = k10 − 47  or equivalently k9 = k3 × k7 − 65.
